reviewText:
They start out having you look at which plants you want, the designs of different pots, the layout and where you want to put your seedlings. You would think this is some kind of a plant simulator game.

Wrong. Classic misdirection.

This game is all about the snail. The snail is the one unchanging variable. You can pick up your snail. You can spray your snail with water. But the snail will just keep going, always in the same direction. It will not turn around, it will not change speed.

The snail is a metaphor for life. It just keeps going.

You can even speed up time itself - the game does a timelapse when you've had it off for several hours. During that timelapse, the snail doesn't zoom around. Plants will grow before your eyes but the snail does not give way to your constructs of time and space, it will move at its own pace.

Edit: by a recent update, the snail now toots. Life isn't all flowers. Kodus for this true-to-reality touch.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I beta tested this game.

Viridi is exactly what it says on the tin: it's a little virtual garden where you watch your plants grow.

The gameplay itself is minimalistic. Apart from planting your succulents, watering them, and zooming in to sing at them, there's very little else you can do. It's supposed to be a very zen experience — similar to keeping actual plants — so if you expect more interactivity than that then this is not the game for you. I usually had it on in the background while I went on with my day as always (hence my exorbitant playtime), but you don't need to leave it on all the time. Your plants will grow just fine while the game is closed as well, so if you only want to spend 5 minutes a day checking up on your plants, then you can do that too. As you can see the joy of the game doesn't lie within its interactivity, but rather within owning a virtual garden in itself.

While this game does have micro transactions, it's entirely possible to play it without ever spending a single penny on it as you start out with 10 plants and you get a free seedling every week.

I very much enjoy playing this game. It's an extremely niche title, but if this game sounds like your cup of tea, I fully recommend you give it a try. It's free so there's literally no downside to trying it out either.

In Viridi you start with a pot, some dirt, and some seeds. (You also have a snail, but he’s just the world’s cutest decoration, not necessarily integral to the “gameplay”.) The seeds are already planted. Your job is to keep the seeds healthy. Armed with a spray bottle, you click on each seed to douse it with a gentle spray of water. You give each one enough water to make it “sated” instead of “thirsty” and then you wait for your little garden of succulent plants to grow.

There’s not much to be done in Viridi. You can move and rearrange the succulents in your plot. Each week you get another seed you can plant. You can water your plants (though they don’t need to be watered frequently). If you zoom in on your plants, you can also sing to them, which makes them grow faster. reviewText:
Viridi is a game destined to relax you during 5 minutes of your life each day. Indeed, like many people said before me, it's more a pot plant simulator than.... well, I don't know.

Anyway, you choose a pot, you plant some seed and then you let the time do its work. You pluck weeds, you water your plants (if they're thirsty), you look at the snail on the pot (I've named it Snaily), you arrange the disposition of your plants, you remove those you don't want, you go to the shop to discover that there is a seed free each week (yay, some of them are expensive and it's cool to have them for no penny), that the price range is from 0.09 to 0.39$, that you can't sell the seeds on Steam Market BUT you can trade them, that you can change your pot if it's not your taste anymore, that after all, you can change any name of the plant, that the shop has information on the plants...

That's what you will find in the game.

And strangely enough, it's relaxing, addicting (well the achievements may be also considered as inciting to grow plants), graphics are correct, the commands are easy to understand (well, once you know that you shouldn't overwater the plants - thanks god, I didn't kill any of them) and it's free (apart if you want to grow plants quickly). The soundtrack is also relaxing.

Micro-transactions aren't bothering here. It's not like you need to buy seeds to improve a character or have a better weapon or anything that will make you advance. I don't bother to buy the seeds over 0.1, if I can have them through the free seed of the week (I got at least 2 like that).

EDIT: since the review, I've bought the cathouse pot that was released after. Yeah, I know, I shouldn't have as it's 2.99$ but at least, I've a Snaily Cat now! Oh and there is also a vacation mode, where your plants will live forever but never grow or flower unless you get out of it. It's practical if you're going somewhere where you'll not have access at Viridi. Also, the developer managed to correct the plants that you're watering by error when trying to remove a weed. Good! Oh and hey, there is a mode where you can enable some singing for your plant. Well, nothing really hard in it as it doesn't require any effort from you than zoom and stay on the plant for seconds. I'm kinda late in discovering this but as I've maintained a certain level of zoom, it wasn't enough for showing this feature.

A very relaxing game about growing your own succulents on a pot. You start out by picking a design for your pot and then choose some starter seedlings for it. You'll start with ten succulents on your pot, these starters will be composed of four different species.

Pot interactions include watering and rearranging the succulents, removing some weeds, and some fiddling with the snail. A free seedling will be given each week. Additional seedlings are available through in game transactions. As of this review there are 22 available seedlings. One pot is available for free, and the other can be purchased in-game (free if you own Eidolon).

The succulents in my pot were able to mature in a week. There had been rumors of them flowering and the reason that I started writing this review is because I was able to confirm that it is true. After more than three weeks, you may be able to see flowers blooming.

I somehow felt excited when I saw signs that my succulents were about to flower. I recommend this to anyone who has any interest growing plants.

reviewText:
Viridi is an interesting idea, and has quite attractive succulents with some educational value. However, the full implementation of this game leaves something to be desired.

This game is 'free to play', and without spending any money you start with a set of plants (4 varieties, multiples of some smaller growing ones) and a single pot. There are a total of 23 plants available at this stage (all succulents). The pot is suspended in air so it's free to for you to rotate your view, zooming in on a specific plant or zooming out to view the whole pot. You can spray water on each plant when selected individually, and when zoomed right in you will automatically start 'singing' to the plant after a short while. And that is all. Oh, and you can look at the snail that simply circles the pot in contant motion, or water it. Wet snail.

Pros Attractive plants which are easily recognisable.
Information regarding origin and naming of plants available in nursary view.
Nice animation of plants developing plays when you first open game each time based on how long it has been since last play.
Free new plant each week so you can eventually have owned each type if you a patient.
Relaxing - if you have two monitors you could use it as a 'background' for the second - just like having a plant pot on your computer desk without risk of spilling water.
Cons Only 1 plant pot - while you can buy 2 more pots for $4.95 each, it is quite pricey for what you are getting - one attractive new location called the 'grove' where there is a new pot, and one very random cat house background with pot.
Extra plants are purchased through microtransactions - each plant is relatively cheap ($0.09 - $0.35), but can die or simply have no space to put it and end up being thrown away.
Limited space for plants in each pot means that if you want a different plant you have to throw some away - there is no ability to store plants outside of your one free or extra purchased pots.
Information on plants not available in your pot view, and if you rename your plant you might not know what type of plant you even have anymore.
Has steam acheivements, but if you care about these it will take you a LONG time to get them, as it takes 3-4 weeks to grow a plant to flowering stage, and you only get a new plant every week (unless you buy) if you are lucky enough to get a plant type you don't already have.
Have to play game every 4ish days otherwise plants will die - you can put game into holiday mode, but then nothing will grow/change. This means if you spend money on plants, you might end up killing them and wasting that money.
Game gets boring quickly as there is very little you can do - quick startup, water plants that need it, sing if you feel like it (might make them grow/flower better), then rinse and repeat each day with very little changing. It says something when you click on a plant and it says 'thirsty', and you think 'hooray! something I can do!!'.
This game could be dramatically improved if you could grow your plants to maturity in your pot, the place them in a bigger garden you could arrange as you liked - especially if once placed in the garden you no longer had to water the plants (gets tedious watering each one individually). Or even if you could place your plants into storage to be reused later if you want to redesign your pot contents or layout.

Also would be a huge improvement if information about your plants (variety name and info, age of plant etc) was available when you click on them in your pot view.

Also, microtransactions should NOT be part of games - have a demo version with the single pot and plant selection, with a full version that gives you the rest of the plants. Even if you had in-game money that you get from selling mature plants to buy new seedlings it would be a huge improvement.

SummaryIf you want to try this game, feel free (since it's free)- you will experience the full game within 3 days (your plants won't be fully matured or flower, but you'll see the growing animations which make the full 'gameplay'). If you find this relaxing to just see the plants sitting there you might find this game is for you, but most likely you'll just end up getting bored and uninstalling.

If you care about acheivements however uninstall it before you mature the first plants (first acheivement) at around 1 week so you don't get stuck playing this game for a year to get all the acheivements.

Do not waste your money buying extra plants that will die or you will end up throwing out due to lack of space.

Sadly, not recommended.

reviewText:
This is a difficult game to write about. I’ll admit that I wanted Ice Water Games last title, Eidolon, to succeed. It remains a wonderful game; poetic, beautiful and awe inspiring in ways that very few games are. SteamSpy, however, is a powerful tool. So here we are; Viridi. The next game from Ice Water Games is a game about arranging and watering flowers.

If I found myself leaping to the defense of Eidolon, a “non” game in the eyes of many philistines since it involves not a small amount of walking and not a lot of killing, then I may well find my defense pushed to the limits here. Viridi will be shunned by many as a non game, but I know that Ice Water Games understands that, and this won’t be pitched to people as a game in the traditional sense.

The world is a hectic and busy place. Just look at the world of gaming; maybe a hundred games get released every couple of weeks, women are poorly portrayed in games while their absence in the industry is telling, GamerGate continues to rumble on ruining lives while attracting no column inches, games are launching in buggy, broken states and DLC and pre-order bonuses are more prevalent than ever. That’s just off the top of my head, my point is - this is a busy world we have created and perpetuated for ourselves.

One of the reasons Eidolon resonated with me is because of that quiet. That simply beauty of being alone overlooking a lake. No achievements in sight, no arbitrary goals; just me and the game. It was a welcome break, a refreshing palette cleanser. Viridi has taken that emotion and run with it.

What we have here is extremely simple; a flower pot with some seedlings. You can load it up as often or as infrequently as you want to water them, see what’s changed, get your free seedlings once a week and re-arrange your plants as you see fit. There are in app purchases, which is something I have never been crazy about, but nothing seems too expensive here. You can buy plants and more exotic seedlings to spice up your garden should you wish, or just stick to what you have,

I’ve been playing Viridi on Steam and I already feel like this won’t be the game’s target market. Coming out on iOS as well, Viridi could well speak to a commuter demographic crammed onto tubes and buses, granting them a moment’s respite from the rat race. The music is gorgeous and the art is wonderful in its simplicity.

Having said that I have a couple of mechanical issues with Viridi. When you revisit your plants you’ll often find a couple of weeds that need removing, that’s fine. But when you do the camera movement is a little erratic; snapping to the location where you removed it. The same is true while you’re watering your charges, a problem that’ll need to be resolved for the eventual release on phones. The major camera issue, though, is that you can’t zoom in while planting your new seedlings, making precise placement in your decorative pot a slight chore.

There are quibbles though, rather than annoyances. Viridi will find a market away from the hustle and bustle of roguelikes and Early Access first person survival games. It’s charming, simple and extremely relaxing.

reviewText:
Viridi is a free to play plant simulator. If you've ever played a virtual pet simulator, this is similar but a lot lower maintenance.

You start off with 1 free pot and a group of seedlings to plant. You can re-arrange your plants at any time or if you become tired of one, toss it into the garden (deleting it from your game).

The plants will continue to grow when the game isn't running so you will need to check in every 24 to 38 hours to ensure your plants are watered. That's the only real demand the game has, although if you expect to be away for an extended period of time there is a Vacation Mode that stops all activity with your plants.

Once per week you are given a free seedling randomly from the available plant catalog. Additionally you may purchase a seedling for a small micro transaction. If you wish to manage multiple flower pots, you can also purchase up to 2 additional pots.

If I have any criticism, it's the interface. It did take me a while to figure out how it worked. Some of the icons and descriptions aren't 100% clear as to what they do.

Still it's a tranquil passive game that only takes a few minutes of investment every day or two.

reviewText:
If you approach this as a challenge to be beaten, you will not enjoy Viridi. It is a relaxation game. There's maybe 5 minutes of play to do every day or two - watch a time lapse of growth since you last visited, pull the weeds, and water the thirsty plants. Occasionally I'll re-arrange the plants in my pot into a more aesthetically-pleasing arrangement. There's not much to it.

It is free-to-play with microtransactions. You can get new seedlings over time without paying, and you also get a starter set for free. Some have complained about this at length, but I feel the way Viridi earns its money is nice. It doesn't push you to buy anything, and it rewards even non-paying players. I have spent nearly a dollar on seedlings for this game and have no regrets in doing so. I'll probably spend another dollar or two on it over the next year...unless I decide to buy some real-world plants to take care of.

The developers are also still making refinements to the user interface. Two of the most annoying little problems I've been having have been fixed in the most recent update. Not bugs, just usability annoyances:

* When pulling weeds, the nearest plant would be selected, moving the camera in the process. Now the selection doesn't change when you pull a weed.
* When looking at seedlings in the store, you couldn't zoom in or manually rotate the preview. It would slowly rotate on its own, but you had no control. Now you can zoom in and out, and rotate the view.

They also added a feature that seems obvious now; vacation mode. You can leave your plants unattended indefinitely without time passing for them.

reviewText:
Do you like succulents? How about neat and relaxing content that is also free?

Viridi is a small (and free) gem of a game that allows you to care for (though the care required is minimal, just as with real succulent plants) a digital succulent. You can water your plant, adjust and move it around the pot, sing to it (which supposedly helps it grow), take pics of it, listen to the soothing background music, pluck the weeds that spring up in your pot over time, and that's about it. The only way to mess up and eventually kill your plant, as far as I can tell, is to either overwater or underwater it. Both are bad.

The game's Nursery gives you a free seedling each week, but its species will be random. If you are willing to pay a few cents for the plant of your choice, then you have the option of choosing from a wide variety of popular succulent species. I think this game is sweet, so to support it I'm considering purchasing the species I'm most keen on owning: classic aloe vera! :)

Once your plant is chosen, you'll need to choose its home. There's a pretty big selection of pots to browse through, and though they're nothing outstanding there's bound to be at least one or two that'll strike your fancy enough to use. After you've got your succulent and its pot, you're all set. Now you have a pet digital plant, which comes with its very own smaller succulent companions that automatically spring into existence and grace its pot upon planting. No succulent in this game apparently allows itself to be planted solo.

And yes, you do get to name your plant. Every pet needs a name, flora or fauna. Though, I suppose it's more like naming your pot instead of any individual succulent within it since, well, see the paragraph right below this one.

You're not limited to caring for just one photosynthetic pal. You're allowed to plant and maintain a whole bunch of succulents in your current pot. You start with just one proper seedling, which you get to pick from a limited, if still fairly large, selection of species. Though the list of starter species isn't complete, you still get to pick your first plant (unlike the random free seedling given to you each week by the Nursery) and once you've accumulated more through this means or via purchasing additional seedlings, you can plant the seedling of your choice in the pot at any time as long as room remains.

One more thing:
Do you happen to dig snails as well? Well, you'll be pleased to know there's a snail that serves as sort of a living decoration for your pot. You get to name said snail and while you *can* spritz and even sing to it, you don't actually have to worry about it in terms of care (the game is about plants and not molluscs, after all) and in fact, all you can do is watch the little guy go 'round and 'round the edge of your pot in endless circles. The snail doesn't grow/change in any way and can't die, and is always the same. So yeah, the snail is bascially pointless but hella cute.

reviewText:
Viridi is a very simple plant-growing simulator that does not ask for much from the player.
This game is very different from the other steam games in which it is meant to be played in the background more so than not. [I did not buy any DLC so my review will pertain to the free experience of the game]
At the start, you are given a pot and a seed, your goal in this game is to grow plants by periodically watering them and tending to their weeds. Time goes by in real time so you need to open your game once or twice a week to take care of your pot; overwatering the plants will cause them to die. The game also has a vacation mode that will freeze time which will be useful for those who travel or might go without internet.
Even though you aren't given many seeds at the start, you can get more once a week for free in the store. Otherwise, you have to pay cash to buy not only seeds but additional pots as well.
By slowly getting additional seeds and by growing and tending to them you slowly make your colorful and busy pot which is quite rewarding. That's all there is to it, grow your pot enjoy the tranquility.

Some pros and cons:
PROS
-Nice fitting music
-Soothing visuals
-Achievements are easy to get
-Educational?? I now know what an Echeveria Lola is.
-Real time simulates the process of actually growing plants
-You can sing to your plants and pet snail
-Yes, you have a pet snail
-Watering can be done once or twice a week so don't worry about missing a day or five
-vacation mode
-You can name your snail (mine is named Moogie)

CONS
-DLC is expensive and not really worth it
-Short sessions since there's not much to do other than decorate, water, sing, and pull weeds
-Not a large variety of music
-SFX is quite repetitive
-can sometimes be buggy, but most if not all are fixed (I haven't experienced any problems so far though besides mild freezing)

So, these are my thoughts on Viridi, and never forget, Life is fleeting

reviewText: It is a good game, and I think people who understand what it is and have decided that they want it will enjoy it, but it won't be for everyone. It is pretty, relaxing and fun to play for a minute or two every couple of days. You get a lovely little environment (or two if you have bought Eidolon as I have) and get your choice of pots and starter plants. Water them, and watch them grow. The music for the game is lovely. Though it has in game purchases, they are very cheap (from .10 to .40 per plant, though to be planted only once and then it is used). You also can wait to get plants, as you get a random free one each week. It is a bit of a pain if you don't remember to come back to it often, as I forgot about the game and came back to all of my plants dead, and now I have one lonely aloe plant until next week. There is a vacation mode now for if you know you won't come back for a while, which is nice, but its like having a real plant and you can't just neglect it like I did (poor little fellows, RIP)

reviewText:
Full disclosure: I was a beta tester for this game.

My life is full of stress and anxiety, and this game has been wonderfully therapeutic for me. No, it doesn't take up much time or require much attention, but the moments of zen it provides are priceless. I confess that I don't do much gardening, but this is a great, minimalist digital substitute.

The art style and music in this game is fantastic, and the succulents one gets to grow are beautiful. Some of mine flowered for the first time the day I wrote this review and it's awesome to see my patience rewarded in such a wonderful way. I find myself genuinely happy to see my plants growing and flourishing, and caring for them is a calm, soothing exercise. They don't require much maintenance, so it's never a worry or stressor for me.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who needs something different from today's usual gaming fare. It's not complex and it probably won't consume your life, but Viridi can really help bring about a small measure of inner peace and relaxation.

reviewText:
Okay, let's get this review done so I can get this out of my library.  (I keep forgetting)

This game is a real-time plant-growing simulator with soothing music.   Your plants grow real-time based on your computer's clock and the plants do look rather nice.  However, the issues with this game involve achievement timing (as in flowering after maturing), timeskip abuse (people changing their computer date a week ahead so they can water again without waiting while plants instantly mature/flower), buying plants from the online in-game store with real money, and realizing that there's really nothing to do in the game.

In this game, you water your plants every few days (or a week) and weed your pot (as in plucking the weeds).  The only things that will kill your plants will be over-watering and under-watering (simply forgetting your plant, which you probably will).  I'm not sure if forgetting to weed your garden kills your plants or simply slows down the growing process.


PROS:
Free
Achievements
Calming music
Great detail on the plant and pot designs
Free random seedling each week

CONS:
Micro-transactions (+more pots.  +more seeds)
Buggy (no pun intended with the snail)
A patience game that requires remembering to log in every few days
Nothing to really do in-game
Gets boring....fast.
No option to start a new pot

If you like free achievements, are a plant-growing fan, or like soothing music, feel free to jump in and download it.   If you're looking for something fast-paced, are impatient, or just want something to do other than babysit virtual plants, avoid.


3/10   (Decent, but not great.  Found myself bored out of my mind)

reviewText:
I am not a big fan of Zen style games in the first place and even less of any kind of game that contains microtransactions, and unfortunately Viridi belongs to both of these categories. Unlike Mountain, in which things happen from time to time if you're patient enough to stare at your screen for 10 minutes in a row, Viridi offers even a less challenging experience.

You start the game by selecting a pot and a set of seeds that allegedly grow in real time. The only gameplay consists in logging in once every 1 or 2 days for 1 minute and clicking on your plants to water them; otherwise they die. And that's pretty much everything one can do in Viridi. Oh, and if you select a plant, then there's an indicator on the screen that you are singing to it, but in fact singing has no effect on the plant's growth. So it might as well be ignored. I don't even understand why the developers decided to add this functionality that has no real use case.

Let's not even start talking about the fact that there is no option to cycle through the plants, so if you have a crowded pot, then clicking on the plant that you want to water might prove to be a challenge.

Once per week you receive a new seed that you can either plant in the pot or sell on the market. It's similar to the CSGO random drops, but at least here you don't have to work for it. The seed is indeed no CSGO skin, but it still sells for $0.09 - $0.39 depending on its type. The only reason for which one should keep these seeds and replant them is if he/she wants to obtain the achievement corresponding to that specific plant; but in this case you still need to wait a few days/weeks/months until the plant reaches maturity.

The impression that this game left me was that it was created solely for the purpose of microtransactions and that the effort put into developing it was minimal. At least for now, buying all the seeds for all the achievements costs roughly $4 but of course, adding more seed types / pots is trivial, so I expect the developers to do that.

reviewText:
Where are we in this game when we step into the world of Viridi? The endless abyss that surrounds the pots. These shrouded colors that reveal an open expanse with no ending. What of the pots that float in midair for which we must care for and develop? What of the creature that rotates around our pot, who calls himself ‘Snail’? So many question around this intricate game.

Upon first starting the game, we are met with the option to name our pot, chose the pot coloring, and later choosing what plants will first start of in the pot. Perhaps these are psychological questions that the game ponders about you in order to obtain information. Lighter colored pots may indicate a softer personality. Darker colored pots may indicate a strong and brash personality. Whichever of the two, the mystery behind the extreme amount of free choice the game delivers at the beginning has an unknown purpose.

There is also the open world, which seems blurry to us. Its color tends to match the color of the pot or similar in color arrangement.  Where we are in the world of Viridi may be in our own minds or perhaps a distant far off future. What is this lonely pot doing surrounded by the endless abyss?

Ever so stepping into the world of Viridi, we are met with the demands of the pot to care for it. What is the purpose behind removing the weeds that try to attack our saplings? Are they implants of evil sent to ward us off the true path of a beautiful TV garden? Are we on a holy crusade, to pluck out each and every weed? They must only be messengers of death, sent to ward us off the righteous path.

Then there is the water from which we feed each plant. This water satisfies our plants. It is the blessed holy water that delivers sustenance to feed our plants. For each time we feed them, we are brought the pleasure that we have just sustained our plants, or overwatered them. Perhaps it is a test of measurement, from which we must measure our ability to correctly water our plants? Our ability to move these plants individually shows that we have some autonomy in regards to the realm of Viridi.

There is also the Nursery from which resides an assortment of saplings. What is this currency from which each sapling requires different amounts? Is this a different form of greed, from which the nursery wishes to extract our personal allowance? Does this nursery diverge from the free path, where the pure of heart walk? The Nursery presents all of its saplings in a glittering array, and tempts every passerby.

And also if one cups their ear to take in the soft melody of the music, one cannot bear to be reminded of their own childhood, or perhaps of a soft memory. The music loops after playing a few pieces and then repeats them again. Perhaps this music is to sooth us while we are at work, or maybe wake us up from the world of Viridi. Could it be the plants themselves speaking to us in tones we have yet to decipher? Whatever the true meaning behind this, it echoes to us and is ever present in our travels.

Who is this mystical traveler that crosses my pot ever so often? His name, which is referred to as ‘Snail’, befits his slow movement revolving around the pot. There are occasions when we can sing to him, sing an empty song to him. I ponder what is the true nature of this mysterious creature? He is perhaps the only creature that we encounter on our voyage in the realm of Viridi. Perhaps this snail is a messenger sent by an unknown presence, to forewarn of something which simpleminded brain cannot process or measure. Our only modes of speaking to him are through a simple song, which has yet to produce any viable evidence or aid. This snail posses no harm though, and it is compliant with being picked up and shifted to a different part of the pot.

Can this game, Viridi, be called a game? What is the meaning behind a game? Certainly attaining some sort of gratification comes with playing any game. The amount of gratification any player can obtain from Viridi is up to the gamer he to determine and to receive.  What are we to expect from Viridi? The game is open to so many interpretations and the realm surrounding Viridi remains a mystery to us all.

They may move far enough away that you may never see them again, but they will have a lasting effect on your life and they will be a part of you until you buy a new pot. Viridi has truly shown us the truth.

reviewText:
What is the point of of us achieving a future in which we all have miniature supercomputers on our desks if we can't use them to spend their copious amounts of idle time growing imaginary plants? Why tolerate an office with plastic plants - immobile, static, an obscene parody of the life they so utterly fail to represent - when you can instead tend a vital & dynamic garden of plants that exist only in your mind and on your screen, but which you can take with you when you leave (without any more unseemly tear-soaked encounters with security guards).

I'm not sure what Viridi is trying to teach me - it's very Zen - or why it appeals so much, but there are two important lessons I've learned so far:
* I need to stop stepping on snails
* I should sing to plants more often

reviewText:
Low-maintenance plant tamagotchi

(As of this writing, Viridi is still very new, and there has been a recent patch with promises of more to come, so certain aspects of this review may become outdated)

Viridi is one of those games which many people will declare not a game" despite the player having total agency over success or failure. The difficulty lies not in your strategy or twitch skills
date: but in your patience. In fact
recommended: by desiring to win the game
hoursPlayed: you are playing it incorrectly.\n\nViridi is a simulator. You simulate owning an assortment of succulent plants. They need water
voteText: but here's the catch: they don't really need very much water. This is a game about making small adjustments. You can pluck some grassy weeds. You can name each of your plants
helpfulPercent: if you want to. You can sing [simulated] to each of your plants
votesHelpful: if you want to. You can water each of your plants
votesTotal: if you want to. Each plant has an indicator to let you know whether it needs some water. It's very easy to overwater
votesFunny: especially if you're looking for "something to do." That's okay. If the urge is too strong and you overwater a tiny bit
commentsCount: you might stunt the plant's growth somewhat but it can always make a comeback. 99% of the time
column17:
which is a pretty accurate depiction of owning & caring for succulents. Much of the appeal comes from owning a visually-interesting thing that changes over time but doesn't require a large upkeep committment.

Everything about this game is crafted to encourage relaxation: the color palettes, the soft underlighting, the soundtrack (the music is lovely, but if you like to leave the game running you may want to mute it sometimes), the slow bobbing of your pot in the game's space, even the menu style.

I suppose the elephant in the room is the microtransaction system. Yes, there is IAP, but it's about as inoffensive as you can get. There are currently 22 varieties that can be grown, and you can get a free random seedling (no strings attached) every week. If you really have your heart set on a specific breed in the nursery, you can buy it, or you can try your luck at the weekly drop. If you absolutely have to get every species, you can buy them, or you can wait for them (with phenomenal luck, you could get all the current species for free in under 5 months).

Achievements have recently been added, and there is one for each available plant, awarded for bringing the plant to maturity. No speedrun. No expert mode. No secrets. This is not a tryhard game, but if you're a tryhard, Viridi would probably do you some good.
